Award.AwardTitle: Twenty-Fourth Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory, and Computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Twenty-Fourth Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory and Computing will be held May 12-14, 2011 at the Shelby campus of the University of Louisville, Louisville, Kentucky. This is an annual conference that has been held every year since 1988 at varying venues; it brings together students and researchers from across the South Eastern U.S. region to discuss the latest advances in discrete mathematics and computer science. The conference theme is ``building bridges between the old and the new'', a theme that reflects our commitment to the support of the next generation of discrete mathematicians and computer scientists. This conference plays a unique role as a regional exchange for researchers of all levels, but young faculty and students are especially encouraged to participate. The conference topics are partially ordered sets, hypergraphs, extremal combinatorics, and applications of these, particularly to theoretical computer science and computational complexity. Applications of these topics span a broad spectrum of natural and social sciences, and form the theoretical foundation of modern information infrastructure. Combinatorial and graph-theoretic methods are used in problems of biology, computer science, ecology, statistical physics, chemistry, and logistics, including problems concerning transportation and communication networks such as cellular phone networks and the Internet. Computational complexity theory is a branch of computer science that seeks to categorize problems according to the resources required to solve them. In many cases, combinatorial tools are used to determine the optimal use of resources.

The conference is expected to attract roughly 100 participants and scores of contributed talks. Four internationally-renowned researchers have accepted invitations to be principal speakers: Maria Axenovich (Iowa State University), Jeno Lehel (University of Memphis), Dhruv Mubayi (University of Illinois at Chicago), and William T. Trotter (The Georgia Institute of Technology). The conference is organized by a committee of seven people from the Department of Mathematics at the University of Louisville; the chair of the committee is André Kézdy.

More information can be found at the conference web site: http://www.math.louisville.edu/Cumberland/

Institution.Name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Twenty-Fourth Cumberland Conference

on Combinatorics, Graph Theory, and Computing

 

The Twenty-Fourth Cumberland Conference on Combinatorics, Graph Theory, and Computing was held May 12-14, 2011 on the Shelby Campus of the University of Louisville.  This is annual conference that brings together students and researchers from across the South Eastern region of the United States to discuss the latest advances in discrete mathematics and computer science.  This year, over 90 participants, including many undergraduate and graduate students, gathered to listen to four featured speakers and approximately 60 contributors present their work.   Details of the program, conference speakers, attendees and slides of the presentations can be found at the conference website: http://www.math.louisville.edu/Cumberland/

National Science Foundation support for this conference provided partial compensation for travel, meal, lodging expenses as well as honoraria for the four principal speakers.  Funds also partially supported travel and lodging expenses for over 30 additional participants (otherwise without federal support), including undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students from traditionally underrepresented groups many of whom could not otherwise have afforded to participate.

National Science Foundation support for this conference also has the indirect benefit of helping the organizers attract further support from the University of Louisville’s Department of Mathematics and the University of Louisville’s Logistics & Distribution Institute.

Over the years, this conference has established a unique role as a regional forum that is open to a wide group of students and researchers in discrete mathematics and computer science.  Especially significant is the role this conference plays in the advancement of graduate students and recent Ph.D.'s who look to this conference as a means to present their work, learn of recent advances, form collaborations, and network to further job searches.  With the generous support of the National Science Foundation this year’s conference achieved these goals. 

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2012
Modified by: Andre E Kezdy
